segments.text: Oh, it was just so cold.
After a while, one gets to where they can only think about one thing, and that's getting on the ground.
Just to get on the ground, you'd fly into it.
It was that kind of an approach.
for me and I damn near wiped it out hitting the ground.
And with so cold it wouldn't have even cared.
There was no heater units at all in the plane?
No, there was no heat in airplanes at those days.
Even if, you know, there was in a couple of them.
But it wasn't effective enough.
You just had to wear enough clothes.
to keep yourself warm, and that's impossible when you're at those kind of altitudes and that kind of weather.
You just can't do it.
It can get cold enough that you don't care, no matter what it is.
You just don't care.
Did you crash on this landing?
No, I got by with it all right.
We had others, and it didn't happen to me, but we had others that would come in there and at other places, and it would be so cold they couldn't get out of the cockpit and sail them back.
Really?
You could run a lift over there.
It didn't have forklifts as such at that time, but it's like a forklift.
You lift them up and take them inside.
put them in a cloth of ice and warm them up.
That's painful.
That didn't happen to me.
You flew the mail for about two and a half months then in 1934?
Yes, my unit did.
I wasn't just by myself.
Of course not.
My unit was involved in the mail.
And then what did you do?
Well, this was the 11th Bombardment Squadron of the 7th Bomb Group when it was stationed at Marsh Field, California.
And when we got over the airmail, we were receiving our new airplanes, the Martin B-10s, which was probably the greatest, biggest, fastest airplane in the world at that time.
And so we started immediately training and developing this as a bombardment airplane and squadron and group and strategy.

spent our time learning how to use this airplane, how to bomb with it, how to navigate with it, how to fight with it, how to avoid the pursuit aircraft and this was the only time in history up to that time that the bomber was faster than the fighter, so we had fun.
We could thumb our nose at them and go off and leave them at 25, 30,000 feet and go on and bomb our target and come home and get away from them.
We had a bunch of frustrated pursuers, I thought, all day.
And we developed the tactics for bombardment that were used on into World War II.
Had to be modified some, but
They were used over Germany during the war.
And what were those tactics?
Well, it's a method of attack.
They would fill several volumes of the book.
It's a method of getting to your target, getting onto it.
and delivering your load and getting away.
And there are many, many variations of it, but we worked it out.
Taking off from fields out with no lights, navigating to the target with no lights, turning in and attacking the target from various altitudes at 10 second intervals.
and leaving by separate routes in the dark.
All this sounds like not very much, but it puts the heat on everybody, I'll tell you, when you've got six or eight hundred airplanes up in an area of various altitudes going various places.
You have to be a little bit careful with that.
to be on time.
And of course, this is still during the Depression.
With the B-10 now, did you get, this is a new airplane, did you get a lot more new equipment?
Yes.
As equipment went, we did.
New radios and other things like that, although in terms of today's equipment, why, it's really insignificant.
But as of then, yes, we did.
Well, we didn't get a lot of them.
We only had one group, for example.
The United States Air Force at that time, well, there should have been 10 or 12 or 15 groups.
But with the one that we had, well, we really did do it.
And how many planes and pilots did you have in a group?
Well, a group at that time was three squadrons.
Each squadron was
twenty-four airplanes.
You'd have usually thirty-six pilots, twenty-four airplanes, and other things that go with them.
That was during this period of time that the Macon went down off of West Coast.
We were having terrible problems with the Navy in terms of whether we could fly and fight over the sea or not.
That seemed kind of like a ridiculous thing in retrospect, but it was deadly serious at that time.
And the winner of winning or losing the argument made
told the story as to whether you got any money or not.
So it was a real lot of bitter fights.
And I was involved in nearly all of those missions that we had Navy problems with.
That was also part of the development.
Most of them off the west coast of California, then.
Yes.
Yes.
Right.
And so at this time there was a heck of a lot of inter-service rivalry.
Yes, particularly between Air Force and Navy.
There wasn't so much other rivalry at that time.
The Air Force and Navy was real, real serious rivalry.
And how successful were you bombing out at sea?
Very.
Especially with the new B-10s.
Yes, well the B-10s we could reach out, you see.
a significant distance.
Three and four hundred miles offshore.
I was just thinking on one of the first missions we went out and intercepted the Army transport Megs that was on its way in from the Philippines.
And since we couldn't bomb the Megs, obviously, one of our planes went down and dropped an aluminum slick.
It was just a bag that had some aluminum powder in it, hit on the water and make a slick circle that you can see.
And we bombed that and went on back.
Before we landed back at Hamilton, that's where we were operating from at that time.
The Navy had already reported the thing to the Secretary of War and they had word there for the commander to report to Washington before he even got back on the ground again from the mission.
So they were dead serious about it.
Now when did the amount of inter-service rivalry start to decline between the Air Corps and the Navy?
Well, I think it built right on from there.
Well, it didn't start there, but it kept right on building until it finally culminated or peaked, I guess, in the B-36 argument in Washington in about 48, I believe it was, 48, 49.
But the thing that finally stopped it, not stopped it, but made it entirely different was the fact that the missile obviously came in and it was going to take over and dominate everything.
And it would be used by all three services, depending upon their uses for it.
And it was so damned expensive that each of the service was going to have problems enough
Just funding the one that they had to have, not the ones they liked to have.
So I think that ended it pretty much.
And how long did you stay out in California training here?
It says that you went down to the canals on this one.
Well, I was in California from February of 34 when we got there to Marshfield and then we moved to Hamilton in December of 35.
And I was there until about the 1st of November of 37, training with the 7th Bomb Group.
And then I transferred to Fransfield in California, still in bombardment.
That's where the 6th Bomb Group was at Fransfield.
And still training.
It's still the same mission.
Yes, that's right.
Well, Air Force, its mission is training.
I mean, we were doing other things, but the mission is training and development of doctrine and qualifying of people, having people so they can be ready to do whatever it is that they need doing.
ASU went on with that.
I got out of the squadron to Hamilton Field and became the assistant group operations officer.
So I got some experience at group level while I was there.
Were you promoted at that time?
No.
You were still a second lieutenant?
Yes, let me see.
there were so many of those that they're kind of hard to keep up with unless they're referred to the notes.
But at that time, you had people in the Air Force who were lieutenants, who had been lieutenants for seventeen, eighteen years.
And I went on active duty, of course, as a cadet for a year, and then the Second Lieutenant Air Reserve for
Oh, I guess three years.
I'd have to look it up.
I think that's right.
And I was promoted to first lieutenant, Air Reserve.
And then finally I got my regular commission in October 1938 and went back to second lieutenant, regular Air Force, regular Army.
Now, did you take a drop in pay when you went from first lieutenant down to second lieutenant?
Oh, yeah.
Well, sure.
Then I was promoted to first lieutenant
Army of the United States, which is slightly different a little bit later, and then finally the First Lieutenant in the regular Air Force.
I think I've got six
There are different categories, different times and all that.
It adds up to a very confused picture.
It's a function of the times.
Now, of course, the times were the Depression and many of the men, like you said, were lieutenants for seventeen, eighteen years.
People were frozen in rank.
How was the morale of the officer corps?
Well, it was good.
They don't like those things, but those were hard times for everybody.
The morale of the farmers weren't very good, or the ranchers, or the accountants, or anybody else.
So comparatively, I think it's good.
They had people still striving hard to do
the very best that they could to make something out of whatever they had.
What did you think of the quality of those early pilots?
Oh, I got nothing but praise, real praise for them.
Very good, I think.
Real fine.
They were a real fine guy.
One of the men that I was assistant to as a squadron operations officer was a man named Walker, who was killed, lost in the Pacific right after the Battle of Midway.
But he had been the commander of that squadron, the 11th Bomb Squadron, when it was created in France in World War I, and had flown with it in that capacity over there in World
And he had in the meantime done an awful lot of studying as a strategist and so I joined with him and two other people in trying to write a manual on bombardment.
It was the first manual we ever had and it got finished and was you.
They were great people, I thought.
Take these hardships in stride and go right on.

I've heard that in the early, or during the 1930s, before the war, there was some problem of discipline in the Army Air Corps, and there were a lot of people flying underneath bridges and things like that.
Did you ever have any problem with discipline?
A lot of aerial acrobatics.
flying discipline and that kind of thing.
Well, sure.
There's a lot of problems.
There were a lot of instances of disciplinary action, whether it was a problem or not, depending upon who you were and how you were looking at it.
To the Army commander on
to or with whom this air unit was associated, who didn't like the Air Force to start with, it was a pretty big problem.
If you look at the guy who was guilty of this great breach of discipline, it didn't amount to a damn usually.
the Army was very jealous of the Air Corps, particularly of people, pilots, because they drew more money, flying pay.
And the other people didn't draw the flying pay, because they didn't fly.
But they were very jealous of it.
Now, you were an artillery to begin with, and then you became a pilot.
I know it was on the
Why did you, why were you attracted to the Air Corps?
Why didn't you decide to, why didn't you go into the artillery?
Well, even during that time, pilots on airlines were drawn 1,800 bucks a month.
And it was, it was something that at first,
It had the other attraction of three meals a day to go along with it.
There was absolutely nothing for a person to do in terms of a job.
Any place you could find a job was something.
Of course after I got into it there were all kinds of attractions.
There were lots of places to go in terms of things to be done.
And the B-10 showed that there was a way to do it.
Pilots also had, well, the guy in the dark leather jacket and the glasses.
There was some bit of glamour to the job early on and throughout the war, Errol Flynn and all of that.
Were you ever attracted to any of that glamour?
No, I genuinely wasn't.
But there's a lot more to those leather jackets and glasses than glamour.
It makes a difference in whether you survive or not.
Yeah, yeah.
But you know what I'm talking about.
Yes, I do.
And I was proud of them.
I didn't think about it as being the glamour, but I think about it as representing what I was doing.
And I was quite proud of them.
Now 1937, in November 1937, is that when you went down to the Panama Canal?
Yes.
Now why did they send you?
Why?
Well, for two reasons.
First place, I'd requested it.
And secondly, they needed people down there to do what I could do.
And so they acceded to my request and sent me down.
Okay, so you were a squadron's operation officer and group operations officer for how long?
Oh, that's until I went to Costa Rica.
It was about two years.
Okay, from 37 to 39.
Yeah.
Okay.
And your function there was the defense of the Canal Zone.
Yes, that's right.
We were the only bombardment unit in the Canal Zone.
Navy had some patrol units, Albrook had some fighter units, but we were the only bombardment unit, and we had an observation squad in there.
During that period of time, you see, 38, 39, when the war in Europe was doing lots of things,
It did many things to us.
We were trying to get ready.
We, I don't mean in the squadron.
I'm talking we nationally were trying to get ready to do whatever it was going to be necessary for us to do.
But in the meantime, the British were needing everything that we could possibly turn loose to spare them, and we were turning loose an awful lot.
So we weren't, our own forces were not getting it.
We were expanding the personnel of the Corps as rapidly as we could, and that put a premium demand on whatever experience that you had.
So experience got thinner and thinner and thinner.
And at one time down there at France Field before I was ordered out of there,
There were five officers on the whole base, and I had seven different jobs all at the same time.
They were cut that thin.
But it shows you what you can do.
What did you think of the defense capabilities of the Panama Canal back then, right before the Second World War erupted?
What did I think of its capabilities to defend itself?
Yes.
Well, it would have had a very difficult time defending itself against any reasonable threat.
I don't mean that as a criticism, because
the people who have the resources have to make an evaluation and allocate those resources where they think they'd be needed.
And I would have agreed with them not to allocate them to the Panama Canal, because I think we had enough stuff in place to handle that.
But if there had been a serious threat, .
How many bombers, how many pilots did you have?
In Panama?
Well, by that time we probably only had like six or eight bombing airplanes.
Down there, okay.
They had other aircraft, fighters and attack aircraft that could have, would have been used, but we didn't have
We did not have a significant bombardment force stationed there.
Anti-submarine aircraft phased through depending upon what was happening out in the Caribbean.
So at various times there were different kinds of capabilities, but on station there was not a significant bombardment capability.
How are the relations of the Panamanians?
Well at that time they were reasonably well workable.
There were problems, but they weren't too significant.
They didn't really get significant until after the war.
There were a few incidents, but not very many.
Okay.
And what was your opinion when President Carter signed the agreement to return the Panama Canal?
Well, I'd hate to express it in the real terms that I feel.
As far as I'm concerned, the whole thing is an act of treason.
Not just Carter, but all the things that go with it.
I feel very strongly that it should not have been done.

During this time back in the 30s, of course, Franklin Roosevelt had a good neighbor policy in Latin America, and often he had American fliers make goodwill trips to some of the Latin and South American capitals.
Did you take any of those trips?
I didn't take any of thewell, yes, I did, too.
I took one of the goodwill trips.
You noticed my next assignment on there.
Sure, yeah.
While in that assignment, of course, I did almost 100 percent of my work was in that lot.
And I headed two or three goodwill trips into other countries from Panama while I was on that other assignment.
And I made two, I think, before I went on that assignment.
I didn't lead them or what not, but I participated in two of them.
Where were they, two?
One was to Guatemala, from Panama, and one was to Costa Rica.
I think that's the only two I participated in.
How well were they received?
Very, very well indeed.
Very well indeed.
It was a very necessary and very constructive
thing.
Now you left there in 1939 to go on to be the assistant military assay for air for Guatemala, El Salvador, Honduras, Nicaragua, Costa Rica, Panama, and Colombia.
Where were you headquartered?
Headquarters in San Jose, Costa Rica.
worked out of San Jose to cover all the rest of that country.
No kidding.
Now they probably have air out of shade every single one of those countries.
Well, I think they did have before this Nicaraguan thing stirred up.
I don't know what the situation is right now.
And what do you think about, whenever you're in NSJ, of course, you're in somewhat of a diplomatic position.
What do you think of that type of position, which is very different from being a military pilot?
Yes, it is.
When I went on that job, the State Department people thought of me as an airplane jockey.
And they reminded me I rank with but under the vice council.
My determination was to make it something other than that, and I did.
So I made my own name both in the State Department and in G2 Intelligence in Washington, which was of course our parent department.
So I got everybody's mind changed by the time I left.
Would you explain what was the problem?
What do you mean you got their minds changed?
Have you been overseas very much in having to deal with the State Department?
No, not with the State Department.
The State Department at that time, and some people would say it's just as bad now, although I wouldn't, were a very superior people in their own estimation.

And anything that anyone did in a foreign country to which they were assigned, they were God's children to make the moral determination as to whether it was right or not and be critical and do whatever else their wisdom called for in terms of family in that country.
And they spent long hours to be goddamn sure you understood that, whoever you happened to be.
And this worked insofar as members of your family are concerned, everybody else.
Well, that's something I didn't like very much.
But I was there not because I liked to be there, but there to do a job, so I handled myself in such a way as to best do that job.
But one of the ways, one of the things I had to do to do it was to gain some respect for 2nd Lieutenant's Air Force, because I was the first one of them that had ever been on a job like that.
So I had to get better at their business than they were at their business in many respects in order to do that, which I think I did.
But I had the advantage of them in many ways.
And I got personally to know the presidents of all those people, their ministers of foreign affairs and everything else.
And I could go and call them whenever I wanted to.
and after I had done it a few times they began to call for me to come to see them rather than some other people who otherwise would have gone.
I think I had the record in that I had breakfast with four presidents one morning in their respective palaces before ten o'clock in the morning.
Guatemala, to Salvador, to Honduras, to Nicaragua, to Costa Rica.
And I had a message for them.
They knew that.
And so they had their cars to the airport to meet me, and I went straight and had breakfast with each of them on the way.
What was the message?
Do you remember?
the U.S. was going to take over all German and Italian ships on the high seas, which really meant the ones that were in port in their countries couldn't get out.
And it meant that if they wanted them, they had to act that day to take them over, which they did.
sent troops aboard to command, to control the ships.
And that's when so many of them were scuttled in the ports and tried to block the harbor and everything else down there.
Now was there, of course this must have been December 8th or 9th or something like that, 1941, right after we got into, right after Pearl Harbor.
No, it was before that.
I've forgotten when it was.
See, we had them blocked up quite a long while before Pearl Harbor.
And the Le Monde Bay in Panama was full of ships long before that.
And they couldn't get out of there.
The Rene Adore and the Andre Adore, and dozens of them that were tied up there.
And they were tied up for, had been for a year by that time.
Afraid to get, as soon as they go through that gate, either
somebody would get them, British submarines, or we would take them in tow or something.
So they were sitting out on the east side of the canal then?
On each end of the canal, yes.
That's right, they were.
But there were also ships in Punta Arenas and Costa Rica and Puerto Barrios and Guatemala and other ports in the other countries along there.
that those countries had been allowing to stay in port and fly their own flag and take care of their own business.
But the next day they were all in a different status.
They put their own troops aboard and taken them all.
Was there a big fear of German influence?
Oh, yes.
It wasn't just a fear.
It was a reality.
It wasn't too bad in Central America, or not nearly as bad as it was in South America, and particularly in Columbia.
One of the reasons I later moved to Columbia from that was to facilitate the takeover
a Colombian airline, which was owned, oh, ninety-some percent by a German airline.
And I became as good friends as you can with an enemy.
to their chief pilot, Colonel Boyle, who was down there.
And we finally did get the government of Columbia and Pan American to get together and act to get the Germans out of there.
And I picked up one of the German Junker airplanes and flew it out of there and flew it back to Panama Canal.
That was just incidental to the job.
The job was to get Pan American to take them over.
You must have engaged in quite a bit of intelligence gathering.
You betcha I did.
I bet I could.
Sure did.

An investigation of reports is one of the big jobs they have there, and I had some problems with that, but there were reports, persistent reports, of an area in the Amazon basin where the Germans and Italians, or both, were supposed to be equipping long-range airplanes
to fly out of there and close the canal.
And there were persistent reports coming out of there of that, and you couldn't get an answer to it.
But at that time, I had a C-45, which is a bimotored Beechcraft airplane.
And with its regular gas tanks on it, it's got about 500 miles, maybe, range, something like that.
But when I got it, I had two extra tanks put in, one in the nose and one in the tail.
But that still only gave me a little over 700, 750 miles of rain.
To do this, I needed more gasoline than that.
So I did something that was kind of silly, but it worked.
I went to Via Vicentio, which is
just over the mountains down in the Llanos back of Bogota in Colombia.
We had a bunch of 35-gallon gasoline drums, filled them up and put them in the cabin of the airplane.
Eleven of them.
I think it was a little hole.
And arranged a way that I could pump out of that barrel out through my window and into the tank on the wing.
So I took off from the Vicencio and went direct to Leticia, which is where Columbia, a little tid of it, comes onto the Amazon.

And then I followed the Amazon down to nearly even to Manaus, and went over and investigated this area that they talked about and photographed it, and flew back to Manaus and up the Orianoco to Venezuela.
where the META and the Orinoco joined, and then I flew down the META back to Villasencio.
About 2350 miles in one flight, one airplane.
And we started about 3 o'clock in the morning, late in the afternoon.
We were getting late in the afternoon when we came back.

But I was, and I never had a ceiling of more than 400 feet that whole damn day until I got clear back up to Oriental, to the Oriental, which meant a good many hours of flying that treetop blind, and I was the only pilot.
And boy, I had my crew chief and a photographer was the only thing that I had in there.
Well, did you see anything, any pictures?
Well, I found the location, and I found a lot of the things that people had been talking about.
For example?
They called it hangers.
They were big barns and lumber sheds and whatnot.
But I photographed the whole thing and brought the photograph back for interpretation.
There was nothing there of the nature of the things that they were talking about.
But it did enable us to close out the problem.
and get it over with, where you could spend an awful lot of time chasing it down or thinking about it or trying to get somebody in there.
It was a thousand miles from almost any place down in that jungle away.
It would take months and cost mints to get people in there to find out.
You'd get most of them killed anyway.
So we got them out.
when we were coming back down the Meta, coming home.
There's no navigation age.
You're still navigating by dead right now.
I flew into a rain storm, which of course you do quite often.
We were only about 300 miles north of the Amazon.
I was down below the trees on the Meta River flying in this rain storm.
which is not a good thing to do in most circumstances.
I didn't do it just for fun.
I mean, I had to hit where I was going.
I couldn't afford to miss it.
I flew through this thing, it seemed like, for a long time.
It must have been more than five or ten minutes, but down below the trees.
Pulled out a nice curtain and beautiful sunshine.
I pulled it up to about 3,000 feet and headed on toward Villasencio.
The sergeant, the crew chief had been sitting in the co-pilot seat all this time.
He looked out the window and turned around and looked over to me and he said, Lieutenant, there are times when I wish I had never known you.
I said, well, we're going home right now.
He said, thank God.
Fine-sighted, real fine guy.
So, we went on home, but I covered that one.
The thing that was disconcerting about it was, on the last barrel of gasoline, we got about half of it into the tank and the damn wobble pump broke.
I didn't have another one.
one of the things that people would say, well, you didn't make adequate pavilion because your wobble pump broke.
Well, maybe right.
But if it had broke three barrels earlier, we wouldn't have gone home, or two barrels or one for that matter.
So from that particular
spot in the Amazon, could the Germans ever have built an airplane that could have fueled and have enough fuel, the capability to bomb the Panama Canal?
Yes, they could.
Yes, they could have, all right.
So it was a realistic prospect?
Oh, that meant the prospect was real enough.
It's just that the intelligence is so bad, and it is so hard to come by, that
You need to be able to look into it so you can quit worrying about it after a while, because it just takes too much resources to worry about it.
But it was a bit of ingenuity that people find out about, and so then they perceive you a little differently, some with respect, some not.
Did you like being a diplomat?
Yes, in most senses of the word, and it certainly was good for me.
I got to meet and understand and work with all of the governments and the presidents of those various countries and the chiefs of all of their armed services, particularly their air force.
And I got a lot of, made a lot of good friends, many of whom I still
stay in contact with.
Most of them are dead now because most of them were older than I was at the time, but it was wonderful for me.
Did you do any training to help them start an Air Force or to help them develop the training program?
No, except in establishing requirements.
You see, when we were doing training, we had another group of people there that was an Air Force mission.
and that was not the responsibility we had to share.
For instance, in Columbia at the time that I was there, we had a military mission there who was teaching them how to fly a bunch of new airplanes that they had bought from the United States.
The man there, the head of the mission, was a man named Whitson.
who was head of the bombardment section at Kelly Field when I graduated in bombardment from Kelly Field.
But he was an older man and was independent of attachs.
Did they give you special language training when you went down?
No, I didn't have time.
I spoke Spanish fairly well from
growing up where I did out in El Dorado and working with Mexicans all along and so I spoke pretty well and I had two years of Spanish in high school.
So, well I wouldn't want to have a press conference necessarily in Spanish.
I could handle, I could get what I wanted and I get to understand.
Where were you
When Pearl Harbor was attacked?
I was at about 14,000 feet coming from Viva Centro into Bogota, Colombia.
In other words, I was stationed in Bogota at the time.
When you first heard about it over the radio?
What were your thoughts?
What were your thoughts?
Well, my main thought, as it had been for some time, was to get the hell out of there and get into the war, because I was stuck in that State Department intelligence setup and wasn't able to get out.
And my first thought was that those bastards can't keep me here now.
They're going to have to get me out of here.
Well, they did.
It took another year after that.
Well, not a year.
No idea.
Yes, it did, too.
It took more than a year.
Until December?
